newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Namibian diamond companies form new association.
newsitem.headline: Namibian diamond companies form new association.

text.p: Marine diamond mining concession holders in Namibia have joined forces to form a new association in an effort to negotiate more efficiently with the government.

Namibian listed companies Ocean Diamond Mining Holdings and Namibian Minerals Corporation have joined Namibian De Beers (Namdeb) and Canadian company Diamond Fields International to form the Namibian Marine Diamond Mining Association.
In a statement, the companies said the association would enable them to jointly approach government on issues such as environmental management, safety and diamond security.
"There has been a great need for an organisation of this nature," association chairman and Ocean Diamond Mining Holdings managing director Andre Louw said.
"Marine diamond mining companies will no longer need to talk to government on an individual basis on matters of mutual interest, but will now be able to talk with an united voice."
The government has been asked to nominate a representative to the association and all companies that are awarded new concessions in Namibia will automatically qualify as members.
The statement said the group would not operate in opposition to the Namibian Chamber of Mines but would be a specialist group dealing only with the marine diamond mining industry.
